subject: Re: [junit] Where the code meets the file

messageBody:
"David V. Olivier" wrote:

> The rule of thumb is that unit tests should be as standalone as possible,
> and dependencies on external resources such as databases or files should be
> minimized or eliminated. This makes perfect sense. Tests which rely on
> external resources are not self-contained, are harder to read, and can be
> broken even if the code is functioning correctly. However, code does touch
> external resources at some point. Shouldn't this be tested, and how?
>
> Specifically, I have code that parses a xml catalog file and builds a
> catalog object structure. I want to verify that the parsing works
> correctly. In particular, I want to make sure that it robustly handles
> unusual conditions such as catalogs with certain branches missing. It
> seems to me that the simplest way to do this is to have a test which uses
> the parsing code to parse a very simple catalog and verifies that it builds
> what I expect it to.
>
> But to do this test I do need some external resource, a simple catalog
> file. Ok. Now I can't simply look at the test to see what it does. I
> also have to look at the file. Are there cleaner alternatives? Must I
> simply accept that there will occasionally be external resources required
> to test functionality at the boundaries of the system? If so, are there
> best practices for this scenario? Am I missing something? I'd love to
> hear peoples thoughts.
>

I'll first try to embed the XML text in the test and use a Writer to test the
parsing. This usually works for most cases.

When I must use external resources, I'll use a JVM parameter to keep the tests
location independent:

java -Ddata.dir=/home/mike/tests/data MyTest

Then a base test class knows how to query for the property and apply a relative
path to all other tests requiring external resources.

Mike
